content.description: Start sitting/crouching with the right hand on a pinch/edge (use it however you want) at 3.5-4 feet and the left hand on an obvious edge at the same level. Make a powerful move to gain another edge above. Another powerful move or two gains the juggy top, where an easy finish awaits.A short, but fierce little power problem that fits a lot of climbing into a small space.
content.protection: One pad, though a pad is not necessary.
content.location: This is located on the south/southeast face of the boulder. It starts just right of an obvious thick beech tree that is nestled against the rock.

content.description: Start sitting/crouching to the right of 'Egg McBluffin' with both hands utilizing a pair of small crimps/edges at 3.5-4 feet. Pull off the ground with difficulty and make a long powerful move to gain the juggy lip (or a sloper just below). A powerful match leads to an easy top out.Â Another short, but thuggy climb. Somewhat of a one move wonder, but a challenging line nonetheless that is currently the hardest established line in the Baiting Hollow/Riverhead area.
content.location: Located on the south/southeast face of the boulder, this problem is located to the right of 'Egg McBluffin'. Similar to that problem, it is located to the right of a thick beech tree that leans up against the boulder.

content.description: Nestled in a beautiful grove of wind stunted beech and oak trees, this boulder offers decent rock quality and a few problems that are somewhat atypical for Long Island, as they feature moderately incut holds on a steep angle. A few other variations/possibilities exist, but the likely best line is not possible due to a thick oak tree blocking it. The good news is that this tree is so cool that it's worth hiking up here just to check it out!NOTE: Ticks are definitely present in this area. Be on the lookout for them.
